options: virtual seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned an incredible amount about early Ming prose fiction and essays. Found some new genres I love and understanding Chinese concepts like qing/emotion much better.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Kang-I is a veritable encyclopedia of Chinese studies, which allowed her to place everything we read in context. She walks us through the texts and is very open to student ideas. She is also the fastest grader I've ever seen, giving us our paper grades back the day we submit them.
Weaknesses: Zoom really made student engagement a lot less robust. This was the last class she taught, since she's retiring, so it's sad that future students won't be able to take her course.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Flexibility with readings was really helpful, especially with many other things going on.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if you have any interest in improving and continuing your literary Chinese studies at Yale. It's one of few classes Yale offers in literary Chinese. You will learn so much. However, if your literary Chinese is not as strong, you will struggle a bit in this class. The reason why workload was rated much greater is because I'm slow at translating. Native Chinese students will find it much easier. This class really is made by the professor's personality and knowledge. Kang-I really made this class, and hopefully the next professor will be able to live up to her legacy.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
